title: Psalms Chapter 83 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 83 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 83 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 83.

questions.question: According to Psalms 83:1, what does the Psalmist ask God not to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Keep silence
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:1 says, 'Keep not thou silence, O God: hold not thy peace, and be not still, O God,' indicating the Psalmist's plea for God to not remain silent.

questions.question: Who are described as making a tumult and lifting up their head in Psalms 83:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Thine enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:2 states that 'thine enemies make a tumult: and they that hate thee have lifted up the head,' referring to God's enemies.

questions.question: What have the enemies taken against God's people according to Psalms 83:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Crafty counsel
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:3 says, 'They have taken crafty counsel against thy people,' showing the enemies' secret plans.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the enemies' counsel mentioned in Psalms 83:4?
options: To cut off Israel as a nation
questions.correctAnswer: To cut off Israel as a nation
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:4 says they said, 'Come, and let us cut them off from being a nation; that the name of Israel may be no more in remembrance.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 83:5, how have the enemies acted towards God?
questions.correctAnswer: They are confederate against Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:5 states, 'they have consulted together with one consent: they are confederate against thee,' showing their united opposition.

questions.question: Which group is NOT mentioned as part of the confederate enemies in Psalms 83:6-7?
questions.correctAnswer: Babylonians
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:6-7 lists Edom, Ishmaelites, Moab, Hagarenes, Gebal, Ammon, Amalek, Philistines, and Tyre, but does not mention Babylonians.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 83:8 mentions Assur joining with the enemies to help the children of Lot.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:8 states, 'Assur also is joined with them: they have holpen the children of Lot,' confirming Assur's involvement.

questions.question: Which ancient leaders are mentioned in Psalms 83:9-11 as examples to be done unto the enemies?
options: Midianites, Sisera, Jabin, Oreb, Zeeb, Zebah, Zalmunna
questions.correctAnswer: Midianites, Sisera, Jabin, Oreb, Zeeb, Zebah, Zalmunna
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:9-11 refers to these leaders as examples of defeat to be applied to the enemies.

questions.question: According to Psalms 83:12, what did the enemies say about the houses of God?
options: Let us take them in possession
questions.correctAnswer: Let us take them in possession
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:12 says, 'Who said, Let us take to ourselves the houses of God in possession,' indicating their plan to seize God's places.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 83:13: 'O my God, make them like a ______; as the stubble before the wind.'
questions.correctAnswer: wheel
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:13 uses the simile 'make them like a wheel; as the stubble before the wind' to describe their destruction.

questions.question: What natural elements are used in Psalms 83:14-15 to describe how God should persecute the enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: Fire and storm
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:14-15 speak of fire burning wood and a tempest or storm to persecute the enemies.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 83:16 asks God to fill the enemies' faces with shame so they may seek His name.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:16 says, 'Fill their faces with shame; that they may seek thy name, O LORD,' showing the purpose of their shame.

questions.question: What is the final declaration about God's name in Psalms 83:18?
options: JEHOVAH is the most high over all the earth
God is only a local god
questions.correctAnswer: JEHOVAH is the most high over all the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:18 declares, 'that thou, whose name alone is JEHOVAH, art the most high over all the earth.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 83:17, the enemies should be confounded and troubled forever.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:17 states, 'Let them be confounded and troubled for ever; yea, let them be put to shame, and perish,' confirming this.

questions.question: According to Psalms 83:10, what became of the enemies who perished at Endor?
options: They became as dung for the earth
questions.correctAnswer: They became as dung for the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:10 says, 'Which perished at Endor: they became as dung for the earth,' describing their defeat and disgrace.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 83 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 83 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 83, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in adversity?
options: God is silent during hardships and we must endure alone
God is aware of our enemies and will act on our behalf
We should retaliate against our enemies with our own strength
We must isolate ourselves from the community during trials
questions.correctAnswer: God is aware of our enemies and will act on our behalf
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:1-2 teaches us that God is not silent or still despite opposition, and He is aware of those who hate His people. Verses 13-15 show God's active intervention against enemies, encouraging trust in His protection.

questions.question: How does Psalms 83 teach about the importance of prayer and seeking God's help when facing opposition?
options: We should remain silent and wait quietly
We must cry out to God and ask Him not to be still
We should rely solely on our wisdom and plans
We need to confront enemies without prayer
questions.correctAnswer: We must cry out to God and ask Him not to be still
questions.explanation: Verse 1 urges God not to keep silence or be still, showing the importance of praying earnestly and seeking God's help in times of trouble (Psalms 83:1, 83:3).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness toward those who oppose them. Based on Psalms 83, what biblical perspective can you share?
options: God will judge the enemies in His time
We must hold grudges until they repent
Ignoring the enemy is the best approach
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge the enemies in His time
questions.explanation: Psalms 83 calls on God to deal with enemies, showing that judgment belongs to Him (verses 9-15). This encourages believers to trust God’s justice rather than taking vengeance themselves (Psalms 83:9-15).

questions.question: What does Psalms 83 teach about the unity of God's people when facing challenges?
options: Enemies conspire together with one consent
The church should compete among themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Enemies conspire together with one consent
questions.explanation: Verses 4-5 describe how enemies unite in agreement to oppose God's people, implying the need for the faithful to maintain unity and prayer for protection (Psalms 83:4-5).

questions.question: How does Psalms 83 encourage believers to maintain integrity and faithfulness in the face of opposition?
options: By abandoning faith to avoid conflict
By trusting God’s sovereignty and not losing hope
By compromising with enemies to gain peace
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God’s sovereignty and not losing hope
questions.explanation: The Psalm emphasizes God’s power over enemies and calls for confidence in Him rather than resorting to human schemes (Psalms 83:3, 83:18). This teaches believers to remain faithful and honest.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear during trials. Based on Psalms 83, what truth would you share about God’s protection?
options: God’s tempest and storm will protect His people
Fear is a sign of weak faith and must be ignored
We are left to face enemies alone
God only helps the strong and wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: God’s tempest and storm will protect His people
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 describe God’s power as a fire and storm that persecutes enemies and instills fear in them, assuring believers of His protective intervention (Psalms 83:14-15).

questions.question: How does Psalms 83 illustrate the importance of humility and seeking God’s name during trials?
options: By encouraging pride in one’s own strength
By urging enemies to seek God’s name in shame
By suggesting self-reliance over God’s help
By ignoring God’s name and focusing on self
questions.correctAnswer: By urging enemies to seek God’s name in shame
questions.explanation: Verse 16 asks God to fill the enemies with shame so they may seek His name, showing that humility before God is essential even for adversaries and believers alike (Psalms 83:16).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 83 teaches that God’s name alone is the most high over all the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 18 clearly states that only Jehovah’s name is the most high over all the earth, affirming God's supreme authority (Psalms 83:18).

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 83, the enemies of Israel acted without any agreement or counsel among themselves.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 3-5 explain that the enemies took crafty counsel and consulted together with one consent to oppose Israel, showing coordinated opposition (Psalms 83:3-5).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "They have said, Come, and let us cut them off from being a ______; that the name of Israel may be no more in remembrance."
questions.correctAnswer: nation
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states the enemies’ plan to cut off Israel from being a nation, emphasizing the threat against God's people’s identity (Psalms 83:4).

questions.question: What practical lesson does Psalms 83 provide for believers about dealing with spiritual opposition in community?
options: Face opposition alone without involving the church
Recognize that opposition often comes from united forces
Ignore the struggles and focus only on personal growth
Compete with fellow believers for God’s favor
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that opposition often comes from united forces
questions.explanation: The Psalm lists multiple groups united against Israel (verses 6-8), teaching believers the importance of community and vigilance against collective opposition (Psalms 83:6-8).

questions.question: Based on Psalms 83, how should believers respond when enemies seek to destroy their spiritual heritage?
options: Cry out to God for deliverance and trust His justice
Compromise their faith to please enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Cry out to God for deliverance and trust His justice
questions.explanation: Verses 1, 9, and 18 encourage believers to pray and trust in God’s justice to protect His people and His name (Psalms 83:1, 83:9, 83:18).

questions.question: How does Psalms 83 teach us about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s timing?
options: We should act impulsively to solve problems
God’s judgment may come as He wills, and we should wait in faith
We must give up if relief does not come immediately
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment may come as He wills, and we should wait in faith
questions.explanation: The Psalm references past judgments God brought upon enemies (verses 9-12), illustrating that God’s timing is perfect and believers should patiently trust Him (Psalms 83:9-12).

questions.question: What does Psalms 83 teach about the role of God’s name and glory in the life of believers?
options: God’s name is irrelevant to believers’ struggles
God’s name should be honored and recognized as supreme
Believers should seek glory for themselves
God’s name is only important for priests
questions.correctAnswer: God’s name should be honored and recognized as supreme
questions.explanation: Verses 16 and 18 emphasize the importance of God’s name, showing believers should honor and trust that Jehovah is the most high (Psalms 83:16, 83:18).

questions.question: According to Psalms 83, what example from history is given to encourage believers in trusting God’s deliverance?
options: The defeat of the Midianites and Sisera
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
The crossing of the Red Sea
questions.correctAnswer: The defeat of the Midianites and Sisera
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 reference God’s past deliverance over the Midianites and Sisera, encouraging believers to trust God for victory over their enemies (Psalms 83:9-10).

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 83 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 83.

questions.question: In Psalms 83, which group is NOT listed among the confederate enemies conspiring against Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: The Egyptians
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:6-7 lists Edom, Ishmaelites, Moab, Hagarenes, Gebal, Ammon, Amalek, Philistines, and inhabitants of Tyre, but does not mention Egyptians.

questions.question: The phrase 'hold not thy peace, and be not still, O God' in Psalms 83:1 employs which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Verse 1 shows synonymous parallelism common in Hebrew poetry, repeating the idea of God not being silent or still.

questions.question: Which ancient leaders are mentioned in Psalms 83 as figures whom the enemies should be made like?
questions.correctAnswer: Oreb, Zeeb, Zebah, Zalmunna
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:11 names Oreb, Zeeb, Zebah, and Zalmunna as nobles and princes to be made like the enemies, referring to Midianite leaders defeated by Israel.

questions.question: True or False: The enemies’ plan in Psalms 83 is to completely destroy the nation of Israel so that its name is no longer remembered.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:4 explicitly states the enemies’ intent to cut Israel off as a nation so that its name is no more in remembrance.

questions.question: The reference to 'children of Lot' in Psalms 83:8 most likely alludes to which peoples?
questions.correctAnswer: Moabites and Ammonites
questions.explanation: Lot’s descendants are traditionally the Moabites and Ammonites, whom Assur is said to have helped according to Psalms 83:8.

questions.question: The imagery of 'a wheel; as the stubble before the wind' in Psalms 83:13 is an example of what kind of poetic device?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:13 uses 'as' to make a direct comparison, which is the defining feature of a simile.

questions.question: In Psalms 83:9-10, the psalmist calls to treat the enemies as which biblical figures were treated?
options: The Egyptians in the Red Sea
questions.correctAnswer: The Midianites, Sisera, and Jabin
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:9-10 references the defeat of the Midianites led by Sisera and Jabin, calling for a similar fate for the enemies.

questions.question: The enemies’ statement 'Let us take to ourselves the houses of God in possession' (Psalms 83:12) implies what about their intentions?
options: They sought to desecrate Israel’s sanctuary
They wanted to build temples for their gods
They hoped to convert to Israel’s faith
They planned to live peacefully with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They sought to desecrate Israel’s sanctuary
questions.explanation: This verse reflects the enemies' hostile intent to seize and defile the sacred places of Israel.

questions.question: What is the significance of the name JEHOVAH in Psalms 83:18 within the context of this psalm?
options: It emphasizes God's supremacy over all the earth
It is a generic name for God used elsewhere
It refers to a pagan deity
It is a poetic invention unique to this psalm
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God's supremacy over all the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:18 highlights that JEHOVAH alone is most high over all the earth, underscoring God's sovereignty in the face of hostile nations.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the literary structure of Psalms 83?
options: A lament with a plea for divine intervention
A royal psalm praising the king
questions.correctAnswer: A lament with a plea for divine intervention
questions.explanation: The psalm begins with a plea for God not to remain silent against enemies and calls for their defeat, characteristic of a lament.

questions.question: How does the historical context of the ancient Near East inform the identity of the enemies listed in Psalms 83?
options: They were neighboring tribes and nations historically hostile to Israel
They were mythical enemies with no historical basis
They were Roman legions invading Israel
They were Babylonians during the exile
questions.correctAnswer: They were neighboring tribes and nations historically hostile to Israel
questions.explanation: The groups named—Edom, Moab, Amalek, Philistines—are well-documented ancient Near Eastern peoples consistently hostile to Israel.

questions.question: The phrase 'Selah' found in Psalms 83:8 likely serves what function in the psalm’s structure?
questions.correctAnswer: A musical or liturgical pause
questions.explanation: 'Selah' is commonly understood as a pause or interlude in Hebrew poetry, possibly for reflection or musical emphasis.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 83 foreshadows the New Testament motif of divine justice against enemies of God's people?
options: Calling for God to make enemies like the Midianites who perished
questions.correctAnswer: Calling for God to make enemies like the Midianites who perished
questions.explanation: The psalm’s appeal for God’s justice against enemies anticipates the biblical theme of ultimate divine judgment found in the New Testament.

questions.question: In Psalms 83:14-15, the enemies are compared to what natural forces?
questions.correctAnswer: Fire and storm
questions.explanation: The psalmist calls for God’s tempest and storm to persecute the enemies as fire burns wood and flame sets mountains on fire.

questions.question: In Psalms 83:16, the enemies are to be filled with shame so that they will seek what?
questions.correctAnswer: God's name
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states that filling their faces with shame will lead them to seek the name of the LORD, indicating repentance or recognition of God’s sovereignty.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 83 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 83 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 83:1, what is the psalmist's urgent plea to God?
options: Do not remain silent or still
Send an angel to fight for us
questions.correctAnswer: Do not remain silent or still
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:1 explicitly calls God to not keep silence or be still, emphasizing divine intervention. This reflects God's attribute of being active and responsive (Exodus 14:15; Isaiah 59:1-2; Hebrews 4:13; Revelation 6:10).

questions.question: What is the nature of the enemies described in Psalms 83:2?
options: They make a tumult and proudly lift up their heads
questions.correctAnswer: They make a tumult and proudly lift up their heads
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:2 describes the enemies as making a tumult and lifting their heads, indicating arrogance and open hostility. This corresponds with biblical themes of the proud opposing God (Proverbs 16:18; Isaiah 10:5-7; James 4:6; 1 Peter 5:5).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Psalms 83:4, the enemies say, 'Come, and let us ______ them off from being a nation.'
questions.correctAnswer: cut
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:4 records the enemies' intent to cut off Israel as a nation, demonstrating hostility against God's chosen people, consistent with God's covenant promises (Genesis 12:3; Deuteronomy 7:6; Romans 11:1-2; Revelation 7:4).

questions.question: Which groups are mentioned as confederate enemies in Psalms 83:6-7?
options: Edomites, Ishmaelites, Moabites, Hagarenes, Gebal, Ammon, Amalekites, Philistines, and Tyre inhabitants
questions.correctAnswer: Edomites, Ishmaelites, Moabites, Hagarenes, Gebal, Ammon, Amalekites, Philistines, and Tyre inhabitants
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:6-7 lists these specific peoples as confederate enemies, showing a coalition against Israel, fulfilling the biblical theme of hostile nations opposing God's people (Numbers 24:7; Judges 6:3-5; Isaiah 11:14; Revelation 17:12).

questions.question: What judgment does the psalmist ask God to execute upon the enemies in Psalms 83:9?
options: As He did to Midianites, Sisera, and Jabin
questions.correctAnswer: As He did to Midianites, Sisera, and Jabin
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:9 requests God to deal with the enemies as He did with Midianites, Sisera, and Jabin, referencing Old Testament deliverances (Judges 4-7; Exodus 15:3; Isaiah 63:4; Romans 15:4) demonstrating God's saving power over foes.

questions.question: Who are named in Psalms 83:11 as examples of nobles and princes to be made like?
questions.correctAnswer: Oreb, Zeeb, Zebah, and Zalmunna
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:11 cites these figures who were defeated enemies of Israel, symbolizing total defeat as a plea for God's judgment, consistent with divine justice themes (Judges 7:25; Judges 8:21-22; 2 Kings 3:27; Romans 12:19).

questions.question: What do the enemies say about God's houses in Psalms 83:12?
options: Let us take them in possession
questions.correctAnswer: Let us take them in possession
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:12 records the enemies' plan to seize the houses of God, indicating sacrilege and opposition to God's sanctuary, reinforcing the biblical teaching on the holiness of God's dwelling (Exodus 25:8; 1 Kings 8:10-11; Psalm 27:4; Hebrews 10:21-22).

questions.question: In Psalms 83:13-14, the psalmist compares the enemies to what natural elements?
options: A wheel and stubble before the wind; fire burning wood and mountains
A river and a rock; snow and hail
A tree and a flower; sun and moon
A lion and a bear; storm and thunder
questions.correctAnswer: A wheel and stubble before the wind; fire burning wood and mountains
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:13-14 uses these images to depict the total destruction and fleeting nature of the enemies, illustrating God's sovereign power over creation and judgment (Job 1:16; Isaiah 10:17; Nahum 1:5-6; Revelation 8:7).

questions.question: What does the psalmist request God to fill the enemies' faces with, according to Psalms 83:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Shame
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:16 asks God to fill the enemies with shame so they may seek His name, highlighting the link between judgment and repentance (Jeremiah 6:15; Ezekiel 36:31; Romans 2:4; 2 Corinthians 7:10).

questions.question: According to Psalms 83:18, what is the significance of God's name JEHOVAH?
options: He is the most high over all the earth
He is one of many gods
He is limited to Israel only
He is a distant, unknowable force
questions.correctAnswer: He is the most high over all the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:18 declares JEHOVAH as the most high over all the earth, affirming God's supreme sovereignty, consistent with biblical monotheism and God’s universal kingship (Exodus 15:18; Isaiah 45:5; Philippians 2:9-11; Revelation 19:16).

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by the enemies' intent 'that the name of Israel may be no more in remembrance' (Psalms 83:4)?
options: God’s covenant promises and the preservation of His people
The unimportance of Israel in salvation history
The universal rejection of all nations
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenant promises and the preservation of His people
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:4 highlights the enemies' goal to erase Israel, but the psalm affirms God's covenant faithfulness to preserve Israel (Genesis 17:7; Romans 11:28-29; Isaiah 43:1-3; Jeremiah 31:35-37).

questions.question: What does the psalmist mean by 'consulted together with one consent' in Psalms 83:5?
options: The enemies are united in their conspiracy against God’s people
The enemies are divided and quarrelling
God is leading them to repentance
The people of Israel are planning their defense
questions.correctAnswer: The enemies are united in their conspiracy against God’s people
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:5 describes the enemies as unanimously conspiring against Israel, a theme of united opposition to God’s people (Exodus 1:10; Psalm 2:1-2; Acts 4:25-27; Jude 1:9).

questions.question: Which Old Testament events are invoked in Psalms 83:9-10 as examples for God to emulate in judging the enemies?
options: The defeat of Midianites, Sisera, and Jabin
The destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
questions.correctAnswer: The defeat of Midianites, Sisera, and Jabin
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:9-10 refers to God’s historical acts of deliverance against Midianites (Judges 7), Sisera and Jabin (Judges 4), illustrating God's power to save His people, consistent with the biblical theme of divine deliverance (Exodus 14; Isaiah 63:5; Hebrews 11:32-34).

questions.question: What eschatological hope is implied in Psalms 83:17 when the enemies are asked to 'perish' and be 'put to shame' forever?
options: God’s final and eternal victory over evil
The temporary defeat of enemies only
questions.correctAnswer: God’s final and eternal victory over evil
questions.explanation: Psalms 83:17's plea for enemies to perish forever points to God’s ultimate judgment and the final defeat of evil, consistent with New Testament eschatology (Revelation 20:10; 1 Corinthians 15:24-26; Daniel 7:27; 2 Thessalonians 1:9).

questions.question: What does the psalmist’s repeated invocation of God’s name and intervention reveal about God’s attributes?
options: God is sovereign, holy, and protector of His people
God is indifferent to human affairs
God is limited to the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign, holy, and protector of His people
questions.explanation: Throughout Psalms 83, the call for God to act reveals His sovereignty (Psalms 83:18), holiness (Psalms 83:12), and role as protector (Psalms 83:1), consistent with biblical teachings (Psalm 99:9; Isaiah 6:3; Exodus 15:3; 2 Samuel 22:31).
